text:
2007  and  24  May  2007  respectively  included  the  compilation  of  historical  geological, 
 geophysical and geochemical data. 
 Previous exploration by competitors at Yeelirrie has focused on the defined radiometric 
 anomalies within the main Yeelirrie channel, where 52,000t of uranium oxide has been 
 defined by BHPBilliton and their predecessor Western Mining Corporation. 
 Several  areas  along  this  defined  channel  contain  tributaries  that  are  covered  by  non-
 radioactive sheet-wash sands and sediments that may obscure a radiometric response.  
 Blaze  believes  these  areas  of  shallow  cover  immediately  north  and  south  of  the  main 
 Yeelirrie  channel  offer  excellent  opportunities  for  the  discovery  of  additional  uranium 
 mineralisation. 
 Areas  of  specific  interest  were  identified  by  Blaze  following  a  review  of  GSWA  public 
 domain  geophysical  data  and  DOIR  Open  File  data  along  the  northern  and  southern 
 margins  of  the  Yeelirrie  drainage  system.    Several  discrete  uranium  anomalies  are 
 present within areas of thin sheetwash and lake cover.  A review of historical data has 
 highlighted  that  there  has  been  no  truly  systematic  uranium  exploration  over  these 
 anomalies.   
 Blaze will utilise both airborne and ground geophysical methods to define the position of 
 tributaries to the main channel position at Yeelirrie and then embark on a focused drilling 
 program.  It is anticipated limited drilling on the Yeelirrie Tenements will commence in 
 the first half of 2008. 
 This location of this work is summarised in Exploration Index Plan A.

22.text: tenements in its Yeelirrie uranium project area, but not over E53/1183 and E53/1184.

23.text: The objective of these radiometric surveys was to define surface radiometric anomalies

24.text: within  the  broader  Yeelirrie  valley  system  and  its  tributaries,  adjacent  to  the  Yeelirrie

25.text: uranium deposit.  Radiometric anomalies detected within Blaze’s other tenements will be

26.text: followed up by ground radiometric surveys and then detailed air core drill testing where

27.text: appropriate.  The magnetic data collected at the same time at the radiometric data is to

28.text: be  used  to  define  favourable  lithologies  and  structures  which  may  play  a  part  in  the

29.text: precipitation of uranium mineralisation within the regolith.

30.text: The success of these surveys in other Blaze tenements has encouraged Blaze to plan

31.text: similar airborne surveys for E53/1183 and E53/1184.

text:
approximately 306 km2 . 
 Exploration completed on E53/1183 and E53/1184 for the 12 months ended 3 August 
 2007 and 24 May 2007 respectively included: 
 •  Literature review and compilation of previous exploration activity, 
 •  Acquisition and processing of various geophysical and geochemical data 
 sets,  
 •  Development of geological models and targets,  
 •  Brief field visit, and 
 •  Development of budget and exploration plan.  
 Blaze  has  completed  detailed  airborne  radiometric-magnetic  surveys  over  other 
 tenements in its Yeelirrie uranium project area, but not over E53/1183 and E53/1184.   
 The objective of these radiometric surveys was to define surface radiometric anomalies 
 within  the  broader  Yeelirrie  valley  system  and  its  tributaries,  adjacent  to  the  Yeelirrie 
 uranium deposit.  Radiometric anomalies detected within Blaze’s other tenements will be 
 followed up by ground radiometric surveys and then detailed air core drill testing where 
 appropriate.  The magnetic data collected at the same time at the radiometric data is to 
 be  used  to  define  favourable  lithologies  and  structures  which  may  play  a  part  in  the 
 precipitation of uranium mineralisation within the regolith. 
 The success of these surveys in other Blaze tenements has encouraged Blaze to plan 
 similar airborne surveys for E53/1183 and E53/1184.

Blaze’s Yeelirrie Project is located toward the northern extremity of the Archaean Yilgarn 
 Province  of  Western  Australia.    The  basement  geology  is  dominated  by  gneiss  and

16.text: Blaze’s E53/1183 also covers a small portion of the Yeelirrie tributary channel in WMC’s

17.text: Bellah Bore prospect area that is not covered by the WMC - Yeelirrie State Agreement.

18.text: It  is  believed  that  through  the  processes  of  erosion  and  leaching,  uranium  has  been

19.text: dissolved,  transported  and  precipitated  as  secondary  uranium  minerals  under  alkaline

20.text: chemical conditions in younger sediments of calcareous/carbonaceous composition, in

21.text: clays or in calcrete residual crusts. Tertiary palaeo-channels trapping secondary uranium

22.text: mineral is relatively common in Western Australia.

23.text: Mineralisation  at  Yeelirrie  is  comprised  of  the  soluble  hydrated  potassium-uranium

24.text: vanadate  mineral  carnotite,  K2(UO2)2(VO4)2.3H2O.  The  carnotite  post-dates  the

25.text: calcrete,  commonly  occurring  as  void  linings  in  porcellanous  varieties,  as  seams  and

26.text: disseminations in earthy varieties, as fracture ‘paint’ on slip planes around the margin of

27.text: mounds, and as grain coatings within the clay-sand host beneath the calcrete.

28.text: The Yeelirrie palaeo-channel is clearly defined by the uranium channel radiometric data

29.text: downstream from the Yeelirrie deposit. (refer Figure 2)  However it becomes somewhat

30.text: diffuse  in  the  upstream  direction  in  the  vicinity  of  Blaze’s  tenements,  where  the

31.text: radiometric response becomes increasingly obscured by thick sandplain cover. Sufficient

32.text: resolution is evident on the uranium channel image, however, to discern that the channel

33.text: breaks up into a series of tributaries some 15km to 25km upstream from the Yeelirrie

35.text: The Yeelirrie deposit is hosted within valley-fill calcretes that are 1,000m to 1,500m wide

36.text: and are developed over a channel length of 85km.  The deposit itself comprises a sheet-

37.text: like  body,  some  9km  long  and  500m  to  1,500m  wide,  averaging  3m  in  thickness.

38.text: Mineralisation is exposed in one small outcrop and extends up to 14m below surface.

39.text: The  present  watertable  lies  at  4.5m  depth  and  the  uranium  mineralisation  is  typically

40.text: best developed immediately below this level in the transition zone beneath the calcrete.

text:
Blaze’s E53/1183 also covers a small portion of the Yeelirrie tributary channel in WMC’s 
 Bellah Bore prospect area that is not covered by the WMC - Yeelirrie State Agreement. 
 It  is  believed  that  through  the  processes  of  erosion  and  leaching,  uranium  has  been 
 dissolved,  transported  and  precipitated  as  secondary  uranium  minerals  under  alkaline 
 chemical conditions in younger sediments of calcareous/carbonaceous composition, in 
 clays or in calcrete residual crusts. Tertiary palaeo-channels trapping secondary uranium 
 mineral is relatively common in Western Australia.  
 Mineralisation  at  Yeelirrie  is  comprised  of  the  soluble  hydrated  potassium-uranium 
 vanadate  mineral  carnotite,  K2(UO2)2(VO4)2.3H2O.  The  carnotite  post-dates  the 
 calcrete,  commonly  occurring  as  void  linings  in  porcellanous  varieties,  as  seams  and 
 disseminations in earthy varieties, as fracture ‘paint’ on slip planes around the margin of 
 mounds, and as grain coatings within the clay-sand host beneath the calcrete.  
 The Yeelirrie palaeo-channel is clearly defined by the uranium channel radiometric data 
 downstream from the Yeelirrie deposit. (refer Figure 2)  However it becomes somewhat 
 diffuse  in  the  upstream  direction  in  the  vicinity  of  Blaze’s  tenements,  where  the 
 radiometric response becomes increasingly obscured by thick sandplain cover. Sufficient 
 resolution is evident on the uranium channel image, however, to discern that the channel 
 breaks up into a series of tributaries some 15km to 25km upstream from the Yeelirrie 
 The Yeelirrie deposit is hosted within valley-fill calcretes that are 1,000m to 1,500m wide 
 and are developed over a channel length of 85km.  The deposit itself comprises a sheet-
 like  body,  some  9km  long  and  500m  to  1,500m  wide,  averaging  3m  in  thickness.  
 Mineralisation is exposed in one small outcrop and extends up to 14m below surface.  
 The  present  watertable  lies  at  4.5m  depth  and  the  uranium  mineralisation  is  typically 
 best developed immediately below this level in the transition zone beneath the calcrete.

11.text: a grade of 1.5 kg/t U308 using a 0.5 kg/t cut-off grade.  It is believed to be the largest and

12.text: highest grade calcrete-hosted uranium deposit in the world.  Yeelirrie was initially identified

13.text: as a prominent uranium  channel radiometric anomaly, which  was found to coincide with a

14.text: portion of a much more extensive area of calcrete development.  Much of the calcrete was

15.text: covered  by  sand-plain,  thereby  obscuring  the  broader  radiometric  response.    However
